SATURDAY NIGHT
DANCES RESUMED
The Cotillon Club announces,
a dance this Saturday night
from 9 to 12. The price of
admission is $1.00, stag or
couple. The first three couples
to be present will be admitted
free of charge.
This is the first Saturday
night dance since the Second
Cotillon. No dance will be
held following the Swarthmore
game tonight.

VAN ORMAN TO MEET
LACROSSE MEN TODAY
Large Turnout Expected; Tech
Game Dropped

MILITARY UNIT
TO BE REVIEWED
Lieutenant-Colonel Clarence
Deems will probably inspect
the Hopkins R. 0. T. C. unit
next Tuesday. At the review
at 4:15 P. M. Monday, Scabbard and Blade bars will be
presented to Joyce Schmiedicke, Gardiner, Reiter, and
Wyatt, most recent initiates.
Col. Deems will be the guest
of Scabbard and Blade at dinner after the review. He represents General McArthur,
Third Corps Area Commandant.

ON PROTECTING THE UNDERGRADUATE FROM
-CONTAMINATION"
We cannot refrain from commenting upon the very ludicrousness of the ideas upon education that are held by high
officials in so many American colleges. To us, who have
almost become saturated with the motto that Daniel Coit
Gilman chose for the Johns Hopkins University, it seems
slightly queer, if not actually preposterous, to read from time
to time of the barring of prominent speakers from undergraduate platforms, practically always because the pure
undergraduate might become contaminated with ideas which
are not good for him.
The restrictions have fallen on various types of corruptors.
•Some colleges object to pacificists, others to extreme militarists some don't like socialists still others object to those
wicked creatures who forsake the conventional and dare to
discuss problems of contemporary morals. The latest to come
to our attention is the cancellation, at the University of Wisconsin, of a talk by Mrs. Bertrand Russell, of whom the dean
of men of that college said "The quotations attributed to her
Were unworthy of any speaker who was invited to speak on
a university platform."
According to the interpretation which we must necessarily
put upon the practice of excluding more or less "revolutionary" speakers, stimulation of speculation and discussion
among undergraduates concerning the problems with which
they are about to come face to face is not a salutary thing.
It is not good for the youthful, susceptible, easily-impressed
student to hear people talk about the horrors of war, or companionate marriages, or the flaws in our economic system.
Apparently, the less they know about the difficulties with
which they will have to grapple, the better off they are!
This introduction of Middle Age practice into twentieth
century education is greatly to be deplored. Can't the deans
and presidents who sponsor this narrow-minded censorship
see that their students would be benefited, and not corrupted,
by the introduction to ideas which are not exactly orthodox?
Are they so afraid of students' ability to recognize the truth
that they are unwilling to let them become acquainted with
"heresy"? For this is what the whole situation amounts to.
Despite the utterances of H. L. M., there are still many who
will aver that, generally speaking, the college population is
made up of young people of at least a fair degree of intelligence. Why, then, is there any excuse for stopping up their
ears?

Gentlemen:
The worst thing in the world to try

to find is a good pipe tobacco that is
well within the reach of everybody,
and at the same time does not taste
like it had just come out of the cabbage
patch.
I have been smoking a pipe for two
years and have just this month started
to smoke a real smoke, Edgeworth. If
at first you don't succeed, try, try
again. Believe me,I tried for two years,
but finally success is more than mine.
I have just been looking around,
and have found to my delight that I
can get Edgeworth practically anywhere. I even found it out at the lake
near Dallas where I go fishing. Oh boy,
what a combination—a perfect day, a
can of good tobacco, and your pipe.
I always thought these ad letters
were the bunk, but this time I know
somebody is wrong and that is me.
Here's to old Edgeworth,
Edmund Condon

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 2, 1928

BARTON BACK AFTER
APPEAL TO HOPKINS
SOJOURN IN ORIENT
FOR MORAL SUPPORT
Havana University Students "Tex," Former Jay Stick Star,
Gives Interesting Account
Deplore Expulsion of
of Backward Natives
Directory Members
Joseph Blandi, president of the
Student Council, is in receipt of a
rather unique communication from
the Student's Directory of Havana
University. The Student's Directory in the Cuban University is an
organization which corresponds to
the Student Council at Johns Hopkins. The missive is quaintly worded and is an earnest appeal for moral
support in their protest against the
expulsion of several members of the
University for periods ranging from
one to ten years.
Political Action

"Tex" Barton, erstwhile Hopkins
lacrosse star, has returned to Baltimore. Since his graduation in 1924
Barton and "Buck" Bonner, a classmate, had been in the Orient. Barton had been working for the Standard Oil Company of New York,
while Bonner had been with the National City Banking Corporation at
Osaka, Japan. Bonner is due back
in September 1929.
The territory which Barton covered was South China, the office being in Hognkong. He was manager of Sumatra and Borneo territory. Oil production is divided into three stages: production, refining
and marketing. Barton was in the
marketing branch.
"The country is very, very interesting," said Barton. "The first
thing I had to do on arriving was
to learn the language, as all the
merchants and servants do not
speak English. Malay is the trade
language, and a trader has to master
this before he can deal with the
natives, for the latter are evasive
and difficult to 'pin-down.'"

The suspension of these students
was brought about, it is whispered
in certain circles, by the outspokeness of several Cuban students in
regard to high-handed policies of
the United States interference in the
affairs of certain Latin-American
countries. To prevent this discussion from coming to a head and
marring the serenity of the PanBargaining Instinctive
American conference, these students

However, the people seem to be
broad-minded about morals. The
day is twelve hours long and the
tropical temperature keeps emotions
rather stimulated.
One redeeming feature, though,
is the fact the most of the natives
are Mohammedans and, hence, have
to take three baths a day. To perform these ablutions the canals are
used. These canals are quite universal, being used for irrigation,
sewerage, bathing and transportation.
Another of the rather amusing
customs is the picking of a housekeeper for one of the officers when
his wife goes away. The wife goes
into town and selects a girl to take
care of him while she is away.
Then, when the wife returns, the
girl is abandoned. Of course,, the
wives seem to think they can run
these affairs better than their husbands.

Princeton students set the pace
for the rest of the collegiate world
and are the best dressed group of
men in the country—that is, according to a survey recently conducted
by a magazine devoted to men's
wear. The undergraduates of Yale
are ranked as a close second. Price
is, as is to be expected, only a secondary matter to these fortunate
mortals whose wardrobes are chosen
chiefly on the basis of style.

Tennis Practice To
George Darley, Jay
Start Next Week
Coach, Is Married
Ken Proctor, captain of the Hopkins tennis team, announced at a
meeting of candidates held last
Monday, that practice would start
next week at the Fifth Regiment
Armory.
Inasmuch as the season will start
early in April with a Southern trip,
Practice indoors is necessary to enable Proctor and Polan, manager of
the team, to pick a team.
Finegold and Broadman, two
leading candidates, will be unable to
make the trip, as they will be absent
on a geology excursion over the
Easter vacation.

George Darley, Hopkins' basketball coach, was recently married to
Miss Frances W. Hecht, of this city,
at St. Andrew's Church.
Darley was a star in athletics at
Baltimore Poly, St. John's, and
Hopkins before coming to J. H. U.
as assistant coach in football and
lacrosse. With the introduction of
basketball at Hopkins, Darley became head coach of the indoor
sport.
In addition to his work at Homewood, Darley was recently admitted to the Baltimore bar.

Galley Slaves
Chained to their seats, cringing
under the lash, the galley slaves
slowly propelled the heavy hull
of a Roman warship.
Today, the electric motors of an
American battleship have the
energy of a million men, and
drive thousands of tons of steel
through the water at amazing
speed.
Man is more than a source
of power in civilized countries. Electricity has made
him master of power. In
coming years,the measure

of your success will depend
largely on your ability to make
electricity work for you. Competition everywhere grows
keener, and electricity cuts costs
and does work better wherever
it is applied.
In industry, transportation, the
professions, the arts, and in the
home, you will find General
Electric equipment helping men and women towards better economies
and greater accomplishments.

IT is
Tonight the Musical Club will
make a post-season appearance in
Hagerstown for the first time in its
history. Leaving the barn by bus at
2, the Club members, sixty strong,
are expected to arrive in Hagerstown about 5.30, where they will
have dinner and dress immediately
for the concert, which is scheduled
to begin at 8.15.
As is the custom, a dance, lasting
until 1 P. M., will follow the performance. Through the kindness of
the sponsors it has been arranged
to have most of the men stay over
night in private homes. They will
leave the next morning for Chambersburg where they will appear
Saturday night.
Enthusiastic Support

There has been a surprising
amount of interest shown in the
concert by the people of Hagerstown. Forty-nine prominent women
have become patronesses and fifteen
men, Hopkins graduates, are patrons. The Rotary, Kiwanis, Monarch, and Lions Clubs have pledged
their support and, not to be outdone, the Women's Club has promised to back the concert to the fullest
extent of its ability. In other words,
Hagerstown is doing its best to
make the Hopkins Musicale a success and it is sincerely hoped that
the club will uphold its end, in view
of the possibility of making this
trip an annual affair.

ON PROTECTING THE UNDERGRADUATE FROM
-CONTAMINATION"
We cannot refrain from commenting upon the very ludicrousness of the ideas upon education that are held by high
officials in so many American colleges. To us, who have
almost become saturated with the motto that Daniel Coit
Gilman chose for the Johns Hopkins University, it seems
slightly queer, if not actually preposterous, to read from time
to time of the barring of prominent speakers from undergraduate platforms, practically always because the pure
undergraduate might become contaminated with ideas which
are not good for him.
The restrictions have fallen on various types of corruptors.
•Some colleges object to pacificists, others to extreme militarists some don't like socialists still others object to those
wicked creatures who forsake the conventional and dare to
discuss problems of contemporary morals. The latest to come
to our attention is the cancellation, at the University of Wisconsin, of a talk by Mrs. Bertrand Russell, of whom the dean
of men of that college said "The quotations attributed to her
Were unworthy of any speaker who was invited to speak on
a university platform."
According to the interpretation which we must necessarily
put upon the practice of excluding more or less "revolutionary" speakers, stimulation of speculation and discussion
among undergraduates concerning the problems with which
they are about to come face to face is not a salutary thing.
It is not good for the youthful, susceptible, easily-impressed
student to hear people talk about the horrors of war, or companionate marriages, or the flaws in our economic system.
Apparently, the less they know about the difficulties with
which they will have to grapple, the better off they are!
This introduction of Middle Age practice into twentieth
century education is greatly to be deplored. Can't the deans
and presidents who sponsor this narrow-minded censorship
see that their students would be benefited, and not corrupted,
by the introduction to ideas which are not exactly orthodox?
Are they so afraid of students' ability to recognize the truth
that they are unwilling to let them become acquainted with
"heresy"? For this is what the whole situation amounts to.
Despite the utterances of H. L. M., there are still many who
will aver that, generally speaking, the college population is
made up of young people of at least a fair degree of intelligence. Why, then, is there any excuse for stopping up their
ears?

BARTON BACK AFTER
APPEAL TO HOPKINS
SOJOURN IN ORIENT
FOR MORAL SUPPORT
Havana University Students "Tex," Former Jay Stick Star,
Gives Interesting Account
Deplore Expulsion of
of Backward Natives
Directory Members
Joseph Blandi, president of the
Student Council, is in receipt of a
rather unique communication from
the Student's Directory of Havana
University. The Student's Directory in the Cuban University is an
organization which corresponds to
the Student Council at Johns Hopkins. The missive is quaintly worded and is an earnest appeal for moral
support in their protest against the
expulsion of several members of the
University for periods ranging from
one to ten years.
Political Action

"Tex" Barton, erstwhile Hopkins
lacrosse star, has returned to Baltimore. Since his graduation in 1924
Barton and "Buck" Bonner, a classmate, had been in the Orient. Barton had been working for the Standard Oil Company of New York,
while Bonner had been with the National City Banking Corporation at
Osaka, Japan. Bonner is due back
in September 1929.
The territory which Barton covered was South China, the office being in Hognkong. He was manager of Sumatra and Borneo territory. Oil production is divided into three stages: production, refining
and marketing. Barton was in the
marketing branch.
"The country is very, very interesting," said Barton. "The first
thing I had to do on arriving was
to learn the language, as all the
merchants and servants do not
speak English. Malay is the trade
language, and a trader has to master
this before he can deal with the
natives, for the latter are evasive
and difficult to 'pin-down.'"

The suspension of these students
was brought about, it is whispered
in certain circles, by the outspokeness of several Cuban students in
regard to high-handed policies of
the United States interference in the
affairs of certain Latin-American
countries. To prevent this discussion from coming to a head and
marring the serenity of the PanBargaining Instinctive

Wife Trading

However, the people seem to be
broad-minded about morals. The
day is twelve hours long and the
tropical temperature keeps emotions
rather stimulated.
One redeeming feature, though,
is the fact the most of the natives
are Mohammedans and, hence, have
to take three baths a day. To perform these ablutions the canals are
used. These canals are quite universal, being used for irrigation,
sewerage, bathing and transportation.
Another of the rather amusing
customs is the picking of a housekeeper for one of the officers when
his wife goes away. The wife goes
into town and selects a girl to take
care of him while she is away.
Then, when the wife returns, the
girl is abandoned. Of course,, the
wives seem to think they can run
these affairs better than their husbands.

Princeton students set the pace
for the rest of the collegiate world
and are the best dressed group of
men in the country—that is, according to a survey recently conducted
by a magazine devoted to men's
wear. The undergraduates of Yale
are ranked as a close second. Price
is, as is to be expected, only a secondary matter to these fortunate
mortals whose wardrobes are chosen
chiefly on the basis of style.

Tennis Practice To
George Darley, Jay
Start Next Week
Coach, Is Married
Ken Proctor, captain of the Hopkins tennis team, announced at a
meeting of candidates held last
Monday, that practice would start
next week at the Fifth Regiment
Armory.
Inasmuch as the season will start
early in April with a Southern trip,
Practice indoors is necessary to enable Proctor and Polan, manager of
the team, to pick a team.
Finegold and Broadman, two
leading candidates, will be unable to
make the trip, as they will be absent
on a geology excursion over the
Easter vacation.

George Darley, Hopkins' basketball coach, was recently married to
Miss Frances W. Hecht, of this city,
at St. Andrew's Church.
Darley was a star in athletics at
Baltimore Poly, St. John's, and
Hopkins before coming to J. H. U.
as assistant coach in football and
lacrosse. With the introduction of
basketball at Hopkins, Darley became head coach of the indoor
sport.
In addition to his work at Homewood, Darley was recently admitted to the Baltimore bar.

Galley Slaves
Chained to their seats, cringing
under the lash, the galley slaves
slowly propelled the heavy hull
of a Roman warship.
Today, the electric motors of an
American battleship have the
energy of a million men, and
drive thousands of tons of steel
through the water at amazing
speed.
Man is more than a source
of power in civilized countries. Electricity has made
him master of power. In
coming years,the measure

of your success will depend
largely on your ability to make
electricity work for you. Competition everywhere grows
keener, and electricity cuts costs
and does work better wherever
it is applied.
In industry, transportation, the
professions, the arts, and in the
home, you will find General
Electric equipment helping men and women towards better economies
and greater accomplishments.

until too late.

IT is
Tonight the Musical Club will
make a post-season appearance in
Hagerstown for the first time in its
history. Leaving the barn by bus at
2, the Club members, sixty strong,
are expected to arrive in Hagerstown about 5.30, where they will
have dinner and dress immediately
for the concert, which is scheduled
to begin at 8.15.
As is the custom, a dance, lasting
until 1 P. M., will follow the performance. Through the kindness of
the sponsors it has been arranged
to have most of the men stay over
night in private homes. They will
leave the next morning for Chambersburg where they will appear
Saturday night.
Enthusiastic Support

There has been a surprising
amount of interest shown in the
concert by the people of Hagerstown. Forty-nine prominent women
have become patronesses and fifteen
men, Hopkins graduates, are patrons. The Rotary, Kiwanis, Monarch, and Lions Clubs have pledged
their support and, not to be outdone, the Women's Club has promised to back the concert to the fullest
extent of its ability. In other words,
Hagerstown is doing its best to
make the Hopkins Musicale a success and it is sincerely hoped that
the club will uphold its end, in view
of the possibility of making this
trip an annual affair.

Alumni Assistance

Pierre M. Ghent, '23, a member
of that illustrious class which gave
Hopkins its June week and Black
and Blue Jay, who is now living in
Hagerstown, is largely responsible
for having the club appear there.
When the trip was scheduled he offered his services, which were gladly accepted, and it was through his
efforts that as early as two weeks
ago the financial success of the trip
was assured, in that enough money
had been secured from patrons,
patronesses, and the sale of tickets
to coyer all expenses of the trip.
The program,according to Osmar
Steinwald, who has also spent a
great amount of time in making arrangements for the trip, will be almost exactly the same as the home
concert at the Maryland Casualty
last week. •

Chambersburg Concert

The concert at. Chambersburg
will be given at.'Wilson College.
After the dance the members of the
club will be -carried, back to Baltimore by bus,, rea,ching the city at

Black and Blue Jays will be on
sale at Hagerstown and Chambersburg during the concerts.
Signs have been placed in Hagerstown so as to help Hopkins
visitors to get to the armory where
the concert is to be held.
